Description: Hollow, cylindrical rod in ivory with turned mouldings, probably part of a handle of a cosmetic utensil, pin or spindle; at one end, three parallel lines above and below a slightly convex moulding, a simple pair of parallel lines on the other end of the rod; the bore varies in width through the length of the object; one end has an inserted peg or mortise; polished surface; surface slightly worn.
Curator's comments: Malmgren (p. 104-5) suggests that rods such as this with various terminals (pomegranate, disc etc) may have been toilet utensil rather like an Egyptian kohl-stick rather than pins (see SCE IV/1D, 550) or spindles. Material identified by François Popin in April 2007.
Bibliographic references: Malmgren 2003 / Klavdhia-Tremithos. A Middle and Late Cypriote Bronze Age site. (no. 160, p. 57)
Kiely 2011d / Klavdia-Tremithos: A Bronze Age community in south-east Cyprus (U.43)
